Woolly Mammoth: The woolly mammoth was a large, hairy mammal that lived during the last ice age. It is known for its thick fur and tusks. Bringing the woolly mammoth back to life would be an exciting opportunity to study its behavior, social structure, and adaptations to cold environments.

Tasmanian Tiger: The Tasmanian tiger, also known as the thylacine, was a carnivorous marsupial that lived in Australia and Tasmania. It is known for its distinctive stripes and behavior. Bringing the Tasmanian tiger back to life would be an opportunity to study its behavior, social structure, and ecological role in its native habitat.

Passenger Pigeon: The passenger pigeon was a large, flightless bird that was once abundant in North America. It is known for its social behavior and ability to produce large flocks. Bringing the passenger pigeon back to life would be an opportunity to study its behavior, social structure, and ecological role in its native habitat.

Great Auk: The great auk was a flightless bird that lived in the North Atlantic. It is known for its large size, distinctive appearance, and behavior. Bringing the great auk back to life would be an opportunity to study its behavior, social structure, and ecological role in its native habitat.

Pyrenean Ibex: The Pyrenean ibex was a large, horned goat that lived in the Pyrenean Mountains. It is known for its unique appearance and behavior. Bringing the Pyrenean ibex back to life would be an opportunity to study its behavior, social structure, and ecological role in its native habitat.
